entry.title: Basic MLP
entry.content:
• Neuron Layer
    • Weight matrix of a layer
    • Synaptic input at a layer for single input
    • Synaptic input to a layer for batch input
    • Activation at a layer for batch input
    • SGD for single layer
    • GD for single layer
  • Perceptron Layer
    • SGD for perceptron layer
    • GD for perceptron layer

Neuron Layer

A Layer of perceptrons performs

Weight matrix of a layer

Consider a layer of K neurons:

Let Wk\mathbf{W_k}Wk​ and bkb_kbk​ denote the weight vector and bias of kkk th neuron. Weights connected to a neuron layer is represented by a weight matrix W\mathbf{W}W where the columns are given by weight vectors of individual neurons:

W=(w1w2…wk)\mathbf{W} = (\mathbf{w_1}\quad\mathbf{w_2}\quad\dots\quad\mathbf{w_k}) W=(w1​w2​…wk​)

and a bias vector b\mathbf{b}b where each element corresponds to a bias of a neuron:

b=(b1,b2,…,bK)T\mathbf{b} = (b_1, b_2, \dots, b_K)^T b=(b1​,b2​,…,bK​)T

Synaptic input at a layer for single input

Given an input pattern x∈Rnx\in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn to a layer of KKK neurons. The synaptic input uku_kuk​ to kkk th neuron is:

uk=wkTx+bku_k = \mathbf{w}_k^T\mathbf{x}+ b_k uk​=wkT​x+bk​

where wk\mathbf{w}_kwk​ and bkb_kbk​ denote the weight vector and bias of kkkth neuron. Synaptic input vector uuu to the layer is:

u=(u1u2⋮uk)=(w1Tx+b1w2Tx+b2⋮wkTx+bk)=(w1Tw2T⋮wkT)x+(b1b2⋮bk)=WTx+b\mathbf{u} = \left(\begin{array}{cc} u_1\\u_2\\\vdots\\u_k \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{w}_1^T\mathbf{x} + b_1\\ \mathbf{w}_2^T\mathbf{x} + b_2\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{w}_k^T\mathbf{x} + b_k \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{w}_1^T\\ \mathbf{w}_2^T\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{w}_k^T\\ \end{array}\right)\mathbf{x} + \left(\begin{array}{cc} b_1\\b_2\\\vdots\\b_k \end{array}\right) = \mathbf{W}^T\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{b}u=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​u1​u2​⋮uk​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​w1T​x+b1​w2T​x+b2​⋮wkT​x+bk​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​w1T​w2T​⋮wkT​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​x+⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​b1​b2​⋮bk​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=WTx+b

where W\mathbf{W}W is the weight matrix and b\mathbf{b}b is the bias vector of the layer.

Synaptic input to a layer for batch input

Given a set {xp}p=1P\{\mathbf{x}_p \}_{p=1}^P{xp​}p=1P​ input patterns to a layer of KKK neurons where xp∈Rn\mathbf{x}_p\in \mathbb{R}^nxp​∈Rn.

Synaptic input up\mathbf{u}_pup​ to the layer for an input pattern xp\mathbf{x}_pxp​ is:

up=WTxp+b\mathbf{u}_p = \mathbf{W}^T\mathbf{x}_p + \mathbf{b} up​=WTxp​+b

The synaptic input matrix U\mathbf{U}U to the layer for P patterns:

U=(x1TW+bTx2TW+bT⋮xPTW+bT)=(x1Tx2T⋮xPT)W+(bTbT⋮bT)=XW+B\mathbf{U} = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{x}_1^T\mathbf{W} + \mathbf{b}^T\\ \mathbf{x}_2^T\mathbf{W} + \mathbf{b}^T\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{x}_P^T\mathbf{W} + \mathbf{b}^T \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{x}_1^T\\ \mathbf{x}_2^T\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{x}_P^T \end{array}\right)\mathbf{W} + \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{b}^T\\\mathbf{b}^T\\\vdots\\\mathbf{b}^T \end{array}\right) = \mathbf{XW} + \mathbf{B}U=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​x1T​W+bTx2T​W+bT⋮xPT​W+bT​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​x1T​x2T​⋮xPT​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​W+⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​bTbT⋮bT​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=XW+B

where rows U\mathbf{U}U are synaptic inputs corresponding to individual input patterns.

The matrix

B=(bTbT⋮bT)\mathbf{B} = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{b}^T\\\mathbf{b}^T\\\vdots\\\mathbf{b}^T \end{array}\right)B=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​bTbT⋮bT​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​

has bias vector propagated as rows.

Using batch in deep learning could accerate the speed of training.

Activation at a layer for batch input

Activation of the layer of synaptic input to the layer due to a batch of patterns:

f(U)=(f(u1T)f(u2T)⋮f(uPT))=(f(u1)Tf(u2)T⋮f(uP)T)f(\mathbf{U}) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} f(\mathbf{u}_1^T) \\ f(\mathbf{u}_2^T) \\\vdots \\f(\mathbf{u}_P^T) \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} f(\mathbf{u}_1)^T\\ f(\mathbf{u}_2)^T\\ \vdots\\ f(\mathbf{u}_P)^T \end{array}\right)f(U)=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​f(u1T​)f(u2T​)⋮f(uPT​)​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​f(u1​)Tf(u2​)T⋮f(uP​)T​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​

where activation of each pattern is written as rows.

SGD for single layer

Computational graph for processing input (x,d)(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{d})(x,d):

JJJ denotes the cost function. Now, we need to compute gradients ∇WJ\nabla_\mathbf{W}J∇W​J and ∇bJ\nabla_\mathbf{b}J∇b​J to learn the weight matrix W\mathbf{W}W and the bias vector b\mathbf{b}b.

Consider kkkth neuron at the layer:

uk=wkTx+bk=∑i=0nwkixi+bku_k = \mathbf{w}_k^T\mathbf{x} + b_k = \sum_{i=0}^nw_{ki}x_i + b_k uk​=wkT​x+bk​=i=0∑n​wki​xi​+bk​

where n is the rank of x\mathbf{x}x. So that

∂uk∂Wk=(∂(∑i=0nwkixi+bk)∂wk1∂(∑i=0nwkixi+bk)∂wk2⋮∂(∑i=0nwkixi+bk)∂wkn)=(x1x2⋮xd)=x\begin{aligned} &\frac{\partial u_k}{\partial\mathbf{W}_k}\\ =& \left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial (\sum_{i=0}^nw_{ki}x_i + b_k)}{\partial w_{k1}}\\ \frac{\partial (\sum_{i=0}^nw_{ki}x_i + b_k)}{\partial w_{k2}}\\ \vdots\\ \frac{\partial (\sum_{i=0}^nw_{ki}x_i + b_k)}{\partial w_{kn}} \end{array}\right)\\ =&\left(\begin{array}{cc} x_1\\x_2\\\vdots\\x_d \end{array}\right)\\ =&\mathbf{x} \end{aligned}===​∂Wk​∂uk​​⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂wk1​∂(∑i=0n​wki​xi​+bk​)​∂wk2​∂(∑i=0n​wki​xi​+bk​)​⋮∂wkn​∂(∑i=0n​wki​xi​+bk​)​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​x1​x2​⋮xd​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​x​

The gradient of the cost with respect to the weight connected to kkkth neuron is:

∇wkJ=∂J∂uk∂uk∂wk=x∂J∂uk\nabla_{\mathbf{w}_k}J = \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_k}\frac{\partial u_k}{\partial \mathbf{w}_k} = \mathbf{x}\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_k} ∇wk​​J=∂uk​∂J​∂wk​∂uk​​=x∂uk​∂J​

∇bkJ=∂J∂uk∂uk∂bk=∂J∂uk\nabla_{b_k}J = \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_k}\frac{\partial u_k}{\partial b_k} = \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_k} ∇bk​​J=∂uk​∂J​∂bk​∂uk​​=∂uk​∂J​

The gradient of JJJ with respect to W=(w1w2…wk)\mathbf{W} = (\mathbf{w_1}\quad \mathbf{w_2}\quad\dots\quad\mathbf{w}_k)W=(w1​w2​…wk​):

∇wJ=(∇w1J∇w2J…∇wKJ)=(x∂J∂u1x∂J∂u2…x∂J∂uK)=x(∂J∂u1∂J∂u2…∂J∂uK)=x(∇uJ)T\begin{aligned} \nabla_wJ &= (\nabla_{\mathbf{w}1}J\quad\nabla_{\mathbf{w}2}J\quad\dots\quad\nabla_{\mathbf{w}K}J)\\ &=\left(\mathbf{x}\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_1}\quad\mathbf{x}\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_2}\quad\dots\quad\mathbf{x}\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_K}\right)\\ &=\mathbf{x}\left(\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_1}\quad\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_2}\quad\dots\quad\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_K}\right)\\ &=\mathbf{x}(\nabla_\mathbf{u}J)^T \end{aligned}∇w​J​=(∇w1​J∇w2​J…∇wK​J)=(x∂u1​∂J​x∂u2​∂J​…x∂uK​∂J​)=x(∂u1​∂J​∂u2​∂J​…∂uK​∂J​)=x(∇u​J)T​

where

∇uJ=∂J∂u=(∂J∂u1∂J∂u2⋮∂J∂uK)\nabla_\mathbf{u}J = \frac{\partial J}{\partial \mathbf{u}} = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_1}\\\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_2}\\\vdots\\\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_K} \end{array}\right)∇u​J=∂u∂J​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂u1​∂J​∂u2​∂J​⋮∂uK​∂J​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​

Similarly, by substituting ∂J∂bk=∂J∂uk\frac{\partial J}{\partial b_k} = \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_k}∂bk​∂J​=∂uk​∂J​:

∇bJ=(∂J∂b1∂J∂b2⋮∂J∂bK)=(∂J∂u1∂J∂u2⋮∂J∂uK)=∇uJ\nabla_\mathbf{b}J = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial J}{\partial b_1}\\ \frac{\partial J}{\partial b_2}\\\vdots\\ \frac{\partial J}{\partial b_K} \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_1}\\ \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_2}\\\vdots\\ \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_K} \end{array}\right) = \nabla_\mathbf{u}J∇b​J=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂b1​∂J​∂b2​∂J​⋮∂bK​∂J​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂u1​∂J​∂u2​∂J​⋮∂uK​∂J​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=∇u​J

Thus, for any income data x\mathbf{x}x, the gradients of w\mathbf{w}w and bbb are:

∇wJ=x(∇uJ)T∇bJ=∇uJ\nabla_\mathbf{w}J = \mathbf{x}(\nabla_\mathbf{u}J)^T\\ \nabla_\mathbf{b}J = \nabla_\mathbf{u}J∇w​J=x(∇u​J)T∇b​J=∇u​J

That is, by computing gradient ∇uJ\nabla_\mathbf{u}J∇u​J with respect to synaptic input u\mathbf{u}u, the gradient of cost JJJ with respect to the weights and biases is obtained.

GD for single layer

Given a set of patterns {(xp,dp)}p=1P\{(\mathbf{x}_p, \mathbf{d}_p)\}_{p=1}^P{(xp​,dp​)}p=1P​ where xp∈Rn\mathbf{x}_p\in \mathbb{R}^nxp​∈Rn and dp∈RK\mathbf{d}_p\in \mathbb{R}^Kdp​∈RK for regression and dp∈{1,2,…,K}d_p\in \{1, 2, \dots, K\}dp​∈{1,2,…,K} for classification.

The cost JJJ is given by the sum of cost due to individual patterns:

J=∑p=1PJpJ = \sum_{p=1}^PJ_p J=p=1∑P​Jp​

where then:

∇WJ=∑p=1P∇wJp\nabla_\mathbf{W}J = \sum_{p=1}^P\nabla_\mathbf{w}J_p ∇W​J=p=1∑P​∇w​Jp​

Substituting ∇WJp=xp(∇upJp)T\nabla_\mathbf{W}J_p = \mathbf{x}_p(\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J_p)^T∇W​Jp​=xp​(∇up​​Jp​)T:

∇WJ=∑p=1Pxp(∇upJp)T=∑p=1Pxp(∇upJ)Tsince ∇upJ=∇upJp=x1(∇u1J)T+x2(∇u2J)T+⋯+xP(∇uPJ)T=(x1x2…xP)((∇u1J)T(∇u2J)T⋮(∇uPJ)T)=XT∇UJ\begin{aligned} \nabla_\mathbf{W}J &= \sum_{p=1}^P\mathbf{x}_p(\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J_p)^T\\ &=\sum_{p=1}^P\mathbf{x}_p(\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J)^T\qquad\text{since }\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J = \nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J_p\\ &=\mathbf{x}_1(\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_1}J)^T + \mathbf{x}_2(\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_2}J)^T + \dots + \mathbf{x}_P(\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_P}J)^T\\ &= (\mathbf{x}_1\quad\mathbf{x}_2\quad\dots\quad\mathbf{x}_P)\left(\begin{array}{cc} (\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_1}J)^T\\ (\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_2}J)^T\\ \vdots\\ (\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_P}J)^T \end{array}\right)\\ &= \mathbf{X}^T\nabla_\mathbf{U}J \end{aligned}∇W​J​=p=1∑P​xp​(∇up​​Jp​)T=p=1∑P​xp​(∇up​​J)Tsince ∇up​​J=∇up​​Jp​=x1​(∇u1​​J)T+x2​(∇u2​​J)T+⋯+xP​(∇uP​​J)T=(x1​x2​…xP​)⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​(∇u1​​J)T(∇u2​​J)T⋮(∇uP​​J)T​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=XT∇U​J​

Note that X=(x1Tx2T⋮xPT)\mathbf{X} = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{x}_1^T\\\mathbf{x}_2^T\\\vdots\\\mathbf{x}_P^T \end{array}\right)X=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​x1T​x2T​⋮xPT​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​ and U=(u1Tu2T⋮uPT)\mathbf{U} = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{u}_1^T\\\mathbf{u}_2^T\\\vdots\\\mathbf{u}_P^T \end{array}\right)U=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​u1T​u2T​⋮uPT​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​
For the biases, substitute with ∇upJ=∇upJp\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J = \nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J_p∇up​​J=∇up​​Jp​

∇bJ=∑p=1P∇bJp=∑p=1P∇upJp=∑p=1P∇upJ=∇u1J+∇u2J+⋯+∇uPJ=(∇u1J∇u2J…∇uPJ)(11⋮1)=(∇U)T1P\begin{aligned} \nabla_\mathbf{b}J &= \sum_{p=1}^P\nabla_\mathbf{b}J_p\\ &=\sum_{p=1}^P\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J_p\\ &=\sum_{p=1}^P\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_p}J\\ &=\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_1}J + \nabla_{\mathbf{u}_2}J + \dots + \nabla_{\mathbf{u}_P}J\\ &= (\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_1}J\quad\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_2}J\quad\dots\quad\nabla_{\mathbf{u}_P}J)\left(\begin{array}{cc} 1\\1\\\vdots\\1 \end{array}\right)\\ &= (\nabla_\mathbf{U})^T\mathbf{1}_P \end{aligned}∇b​J​=p=1∑P​∇b​Jp​=p=1∑P​∇up​​Jp​=p=1∑P​∇up​​J=∇u1​​J+∇u2​​J+⋯+∇uP​​J=(∇u1​​J∇u2​​J…∇uP​​J)⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​11⋮1​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=(∇U​)T1P​​

where 1P=(1,1,…,1)T\mathbf{1}_P = (1, 1, \dots, 1)^T1P​=(1,1,…,1)T is a vector of PPP ones.

That is, by computing gradient ∇UJ\nabla_\mathbf{U}J∇U​J with respect to synaptic input, the weights and biases can be updated.

Perceptron Layer

A layer of perceptrons performs multidimensional non-linear regression and learns a multidimensional non-linear mapping:

ϕ=Rn→RK\phi = \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^K ϕ=Rn→RK

SGD for perceptron layer

Given a training pattern (x,d)(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{d})(x,d), note x=(x1,x2,…,xn)T∈Rn\mathbf{x} = (x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n)^T \in \mathbb{R}^nx=(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)T∈Rn and d=(d1,d2,…,dK)T∈RK\mathbf{d} = (d_1, d_2, \dots, d_K)^T\in \mathbb{R}^Kd=(d1​,d2​,…,dK​)T∈RK. The square error cost function is:

J=12∑k=1K(dk−yk)2J = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^K(d_k - y_k)^2 J=21​k=1∑K​(dk​−yk​)2

where yk=f(uk)=11+e−uky_k = f(u_k) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-u_k}}yk​=f(uk​)=1+e−uk​1​ and uk=xTwk+bku_k = \mathbf{x}^T\mathbf{w}_k + b_kuk​=xTwk​+bk​. uk\mathbf{u_k}uk​ is the synaptic input of the kkkth neuron. JJJ is the sum of square errors of all the nueron outputs. Gradient of JJJ with respect to uku_kuk​ is:

∂J∂uk=∂J∂yk∂yk∂uk=−(dk−yk)∂yk∂uk=−(dk−yk)f′(uk)\frac{\partial J}{\partial u_k} = \frac{\partial J}{\partial y_k}\frac{\partial y_k}{\partial u_k} = -(d_k - y_k)\frac{\partial y_k}{\partial u_k} = -(d_k - y_k)f'(u_k) ∂uk​∂J​=∂yk​∂J​∂uk​∂yk​​=−(dk​−yk​)∂uk​∂yk​​=−(dk​−yk​)f′(uk​)

Substituting ∇ukJ=∂J∂uk=−(dk−yk)f′(uk)\nabla_{u_k}J = \frac{\partial J}{\partial u_k} = -(d_k - y_k)f'(u_k)∇uk​​J=∂uk​∂J​=−(dk​−yk​)f′(uk​):

∇uJ=−((d1−y1)f′(u1)(d2−y2)f′(u2)⋮(d1−y1)f′(u1))=−(d−y)⋅f′(u)\nabla_\mathbf{u}J = -\left(\begin{array}{cc} (d_1 - y_1)f'(u_1)\\(d_2 - y_2)f'(u_2)\\\vdots\\(d_1 - y_1)f'(u_1) \end{array}\right) = -(\mathbf{d} - \mathbf{y})\cdot f'(\mathbf{u})∇u​J=−⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​(d1​−y1​)f′(u1​)(d2​−y2​)f′(u2​)⋮(d1​−y1​)f′(u1​)​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​=−(d−y)⋅f′(u)

where “⋅\cdot⋅” means element-wise multiplication.

The algorithm is:

Given a training dataset{(x,d)}Set learning parameter αInitialize W and bRepeat until convergence:For every pattern (x,d):u=WTx+by=f(u)=11+e−u∇uJ=−(d−y)⋅f′(u)∇WJ=x(∇uJ)T∇bJ=∇uJW←W−α∇WJb←b−α∇bJ\begin{aligned} &\text{Given a training dataset} \{(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{d})\}\\ &\text{Set learning parameter }\alpha\\ &\text{Initialize $\mathbf{W}$ and $\mathbf{b}$}\\ &\text{Repeat until convergence:}\\ &\qquad\text{For every pattern }(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{d}):\\ &\qquad\qquad \mathbf{u} = \mathbf{W}^T\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{b}\\ &\qquad\qquad \mathbf{y} = f(\mathbf{u}) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-\mathbf{u}}}\\ &\qquad\qquad\nabla_\mathbf{u}J = -(\mathbf{d} - \mathbf{y})\cdot f'(\mathbf{u})\\ &\qquad\qquad\nabla_\mathbf{W}J = \mathbf{x}(\nabla_\mathbf{u}J)^T\\ &\qquad\qquad\nabla_\mathbf{b}J = \nabla_\mathbf{u}J\\ &\qquad\qquad\mathbf{W}\leftarrow\mathbf{W} - \alpha\nabla_\mathbf{W}J\\ &\qquad\qquad\mathbf{b}\leftarrow\mathbf{b} - \alpha\nabla_\mathbf{b}J \end{aligned}​Given a training dataset{(x,d)}Set learning parameter αInitialize W and bRepeat until convergence:For every pattern (x,d):u=WTx+by=f(u)=1+e−u1​∇u​J=−(d−y)⋅f′(u)∇W​J=x(∇u​J)T∇b​J=∇u​JW←W−α∇W​Jb←b−α∇b​J​

GD for perceptron layer

Given a training dataset {xp,dp}p=1P\{\mathbf{x}_p, \mathbf{d}_p\}_{p=1}^P{xp​,dp​}p=1P​. Note xp=(xp1,xp2,…,xpn)T∈Rn\mathbf{x}_p = (x_{p1}, x_{p2}, \dots, x_{pn})^T \in \mathbb{R}^nxp​=(xp1​,xp2​,…,xpn​)T∈Rn and dp=(dp1,dp2,…,dpK)T∈RK\mathbf{d}_p = (d_{p1}, d_{p2}, \dots, d_{pK})^T\in \mathbb{R}^Kdp​=(dp1​,dp2​,…,dpK​)T∈RK.

The cost function JJJ is given by the sum of square errors:

J=12∑p=1P∑k=1K(dpk−ypk)2J = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{p=1}^P\sum_{k=1}^K(d_{pk} - y_{pk})^2 J=21​p=1∑P​k=1∑K​(dpk​−ypk​)2

JJJ can be written as the sum of cost due to individual patterns:

J=∑p=1PJpJ = \sum_{p=1}^PJ_p J=p=1∑P​Jp​

where Jp=12∑k=1K(dpk−ypk)2J_p = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^K(d_{pk} - y_{pk})^2Jp​=21​∑k=1K​(dpk​−ypk​)2 is the square error for the pppth pattern.
